texts.definition: Physical props that are shipped with the games to strengthen the game experience.
markups: <style="Definition">Physical props that are shipped with the games to strengthen the game experience.</style>

Games are typically designed to provide a certain type of experience regarding the game world or gameplay. One way this can be supported outside the game is through various props, <style="CurrentLink">Feelies</style>, shipped with the games.

Wikipedia has a page describing [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feelie feelies] and GiantBomb has a [http://www.giantbomb.com/feelie/3015-6440/ list] of games with <style="CurrentLink">Feelies</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Feelies</style> were most common in Infocom games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Planetfall">Planetfall</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zork%20series">Zork series</link></style>. However, they are also packaged with some ''collector's'' editions of games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dead%20Rising%202">Dead Rising 2</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%204%20Pip-Boy%20Edition">Fallout 4 Pip-Boy Edition</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Feelies</style> are a type of <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style> so the main design challenges associated with them are similar to those of <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style> in general except for the physical design of them. Since <style="CurrentLink">Feelies</style> are extra elements provided specifically to provide additional experiences the diegetic and narration aspects of them, for example supporting <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, become even more important to them than to other game elements. One particular choice they offer is to give players <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> or to provide <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style> for them.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maps">Maps</link></style> can be used specifically to provide <style="CurrentLink">Feelies</style>. Another option is to create <style="Link"><link="player-aids">Player Aids</link></style> that have <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> as well as <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> for its medium (not all <style="CurrentLink">Feelies</style> are <style="Link"><link="player-aids">Player Aids</link></style> since not all of them provide narrative or gameplay information).

<style="CurrentLink">Feelies</style> are basically a type of <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style> that exist outside the main medium of a game in order to give <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>. By doing so they show the simplest way of creating <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transmedia%20Games">Transmedia Games</link></style> and their special status of being physical make them <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>. They are typically design to support both <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>.

While many times <style="CurrentLink">Feelies</style> simply provide extra experiential value to a game, they sometimes also can help gameplay. One example of this is the map of the Underground Empire shipped together with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zork%20I">Zork I</link></style> which gives some hints to players.

Feelies can arguably be said to provide <style="Link"><link="extra-game-broadcasting">Extra-Game Broadcasting</link></style> when they depict events that have taken place in the game world, e.g. the diary provided with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Planetfall">Planetfall</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="extra-game-broadcasting">Extra-Game Broadcasting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transmedia%20Games">Transmedia Games</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="player-aids">Player Aids</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>
